description.narrative: 1. Number of statistical areas assessed towards compliance with international/EU standards in statistics & policy-makers’ needs. 2. Number of methodologies and toolkits (incl. administrative data sources) developed/ revised from the perspective on international/EU requirements in statistics 3. Number of tools focused and actions on “quality of statistical output” developed to comply with European norms and best practices and to build necessary national capacities 4. Number of statistical surveys designed (complying with international/EU requirements) and carried out to respond to policy-making information needs 5. Number of stat.staff whose capacities to collect & produce quality disaggregated data within statistical sample surveys are built, by topics explored, to make more data available for the research and policy development 6. Number of professional development events carried out and/or training materials (curriculum, manuals, guides) for stat.staff implemented 7. Number of user-friendly statistical outputs developed & disseminated, no of areas covered 8. Level of data users’ satisfaction with statistical outputs periodically measured and feedback provided 9. Number of data user capacity building initiatives carried out/institutionalized, topics covered, trainees from Gov., CSOs, media whose statistical literacy strengthened 10. Number of policy documents being assisted with M&E tools (stat.indicators, guidance) to contribute to their efficiency and effectiveness 11. Number of research/analytical papers to analyze less explored topics developed on the basis of available statistics in participatory manner

comment.narrative: 1. Statistical areas are not assessed on compliance with EU requirements/standards 2. Moldovan statistical system still suffers from inconsistent methodologies, multiplicity of data sources, fragmented statistical activities in line ministries 3. Data production systems are not fully covered by the international standards related to quaility of statistical outputs and processes 4. Insufficient number and varity of statistical surveys to cover all the information needs 5. Inadequate resources and lack of continuous training and capacity building for statisticians 6. There are limited opportunities for professional development of data producers to comply with actual requirements and international standards in the field 7. Data dissemination covers only core statistical areas and is done through traditional means of communication; 8. Most of indicators are not disaggregated by sex, age, and geographical territory; and even existing disaggregated indicators are often not disseminated and are not easily accessible which do not meet users' needs and satisfaction. 9. Data users have insufficient skills and capacities to efficiently use statistics for participatory policy-making 10. Government’s monitoring & evaluation capacities are weak 11. Data/evidence-based analysis is poorly applied to analyze the current situation, develop policies, monitor their implementation and evaluate impact, as well as to assess to what extent Moldova is fulfilling its obligations under economic, social and cultural rights.

1. At least 3 stat. areas assessed towards compliance with international standards to enable the measurement of certain targets under SDGs agenda, including through gender perspective. 2. At least 2 sets of statistical methodologies and questionnaires developed to enable data collection in 2 areas which are relevant to SDGs (Goal 10, 5 - Men/Women Entrepreneurship and ICT activity of population) 3. Not applicable in 2016. 4. At least 2 statistical surveys designed and piloted in 2 areas which are relevant to SDGs (Goal 10, 5 - Men/Women Entrepreneurship and ICT activity of population) 5. At least 4 statisticians and 5 interviewers benefit of on-the-job training on collection or production of disaggregated data in at least 2 areas (inequality and ICT) 6. Not applicable in 2016. 7. One e-solution on gender statistics’ visual dissemination developed and operationalized to improve data use/application for policy making 8. One up-to-date report to assess the users’ satisfaction and information needs developed 9. At least 2 capacity building activities carried out for data users (policy-makers, CSOs, etc.) on at least 2 topics of statistics 10. M&E tools (statistical indicators and methodological guidance) developed to support at least 2 policy documents; Technical guidance and conceptual support provided to at least 3 UN/DP Projects to enable and facilitate the M&E under UNPF 11. 10 profiles on vulnerable groups of women disseminated (in at least 3 formats)

1. 3 statistical areas assessed (poverty, ICT, entrepreneourship) 2. 2 statistical methodologies and 1 questionnaire (Goal 10 – multi-dimensional poverty, 5 - Men/Women Entrepreneurship) 3. Not applicable in 2016. 4. 1 statistical survey designed (Goal 5 - Men/Women Entrepreneurship) 5. 4 statisticians and 5 interviewers trained in 2 areas (multi-dimensional poverty and Men/Women Entrepreneurship) 6. Not applicable in 2016. 7. One e-solution developed and operationalized 8. One report to assess the users’ satisfaction developed 9. 3 capacity building activities carried out for data users (policy-makers, CSOs, etc.) on 3 topics of statistics (Multi-dimensional Poverty Index, Women profiles, gender statistics) 10. Guidance and conceptual support provided to 2 UNDP Projects and UNCT 11. 10 women profiles disseminated (in 3 formats – 10 analytical briefs, 11 infographs, (social) media communications)

1. At least 5 statistical areas covering Women in ICT assessed towards compliance with international/EU standards in statistics & policy-makers’ needs 2. At least 3 stat. methodology and/or toolkits revised and/or improved to enable the measurement of certain targets under SDGs agenda, including through gender perspective 3. Not applicable in 2017. 4. Stat.methodology, questionnare piloted by NBS to collect data in enterprises regarding the Women Entrepreneurship. 5. At least 20 stat.staff of NBS whose capacities to collect & produce quality disaggregated data within statistical sample surveys are built, on the topic of Women Entrepreneurship. 6. Not applicable in 2017. 7. E-solution on gender statistics dissemination operationalised to improve data use/application for policy making 9. Not applicable in 2017. 10. NBS supported to develop a mid-term Operation Plan (2018-2020) for the implementation of the Strategy on National Statistical System 2016-2020. 11. At least one analytical paper to analyze Women in ICT developed on the basis of available statistics

1. 8 statistical areas covering Women in ICT assessed towards compliance with international/EU standards in statistics & policy-makers’ needs 2. Recommendations were made to revise and improve the stat. methodology for the ICT indicators which would enable the measurement of certain targets under SDGs, through gender perspective 3. Not applicable in 2017. 4. Stat.methodology, questionnaire piloted by NBS to collect data in enterprises regarding the Women Entrepreneurship (in the process of implementation - tbc) 5. At least 20 stat.staff of NBS whose capacities to collect & produce quality disaggregated data within statistical sample surveys are built, on the topic of Women Entrepreneurship. (in the process of implementation - tbc) 6. Not applicable in 2017. 7. One e-solution (GenderPulse) on gender statistics dissemination operationalised to improve data use/application for policy making (in Romanian and English) 9. Not applicable in 2017. 10. NBS supported to develop a mid-term Operation Plan (2018-2020) for the implementation of the Strategy on National Statistical System 2016-2020. 11. One analytical brief on Role of Women in ICT is under development on the basis of available statistics, gathered during the inventory of national statistics.

1. SDGs indicators that were adopted at national level revised and national roadmap developed to guide the work required on the improvement of SDGs data 2. At least 3 stat. methodologies and/or toolkits developed/ improved to enable production of SDGs indicators by NBS, by appropriate disaggregation (by gender, age, etc.) 3. National metadata on SDGs indicators produced by NBS developed 4. Statistical survey on Women Entrepreneurship carried out and output indicators produced 5. Personnel of Territorial Statistical Offices trained on methodological and data collection aspects to facilitate data collection within the Women Entrepreneurship Survey 6. Content of the training materials developed to enable the design and programming of an e-learning platform for continuous professional training of specialists in the field of official statistics 7. E-solution on gender statistics dissemination complemented with additional indicators 8. Not applicable for 2018 9. At least 2 capacity building activities carried out for data users (policy-makers, CSOs, etc.) on at least 2 topics of statistics (Women Entrepreneurship and gender statistics) 10. Requirements for setting up a National dashboard on communication & dissemination of SDGs indicators drafted to facilitate the SDGs' monitoring and reporting by the government 11. description.narrative: Elections - elections

1. Active women’s caucus exists, or increase in activity of caucus that supports legislation for advancement of women. 2. Level of compliance with international human rights instruments of policy and law-making actions and availability and implementation of rules and procedures for cooperation between the Parliamentary Advocates and the Parliament. 3. Availability of a revised/adjusted human resource policy in the Parliament, its regulations on the civil servants activity, job descriptions, performance measurement tools etc. 4. Parliament’s Secretariat has developed and implements a Strategic Development Plan. 5. Level of participation of citizens in the democratic life through more active outreach of MPs outside the capital. 6. Availability of systems and processes for legislative research and outreach (information, dissemination and responsiveness to citizen constituents). 7. Number of legislators/staff trained on law making techniques, procedures and processes in compliance with the international standards.

comment.narrative: 1. Little or no consideration of gender issues in the legislative process and no dedicated body to address gender equality issues in the Parliament. 2. An ineffective parliamentary oversight on human rights. The cooperation between Parliament and Ombudsman institution is rather weak. 3. Underdeveloped human resources management system. 4.Parliament’s Secretariat doesn’t have a Strategic Development Plan. 5.Moldova's challenges to the emergence of a high quality representative relationship between citizens and parliamentarians. 6. There are weak systems and processes for legislative research and outreach. 7. The legislative and analytic skills of secretariat’s legal and research staff, as well as the MPs, require improvement.

1. Parliament Women’s Caucus is operational and supports legislation for advancement of women. 2. Guidance for strengthening the oversight role of the Human Rights Committee in relation to UPR’s recommendations provided. 3. Achieved in 2013. National GOPAC chapter (anti-corruption caucus) in Parliament of Moldova established. 4. Functional analyses of Parliament Secretariat performed. A new Strategic Plan of Parliament Secretariat developed and approved by Parliament; 5. Evaluation of efficiency of the parliamentary constituency offices (PTIOs) for the possible full roll-out of the PTIOs model conducted. 6. Communication Strategy of the Parliament developed. SOP on parliamentary transparency and access to information developed. Open Parliament Action Plan for Parliament of Moldova developed. 7. At least 15 Members of Parliament and parliamentary staff and 5 members of People’s Assembly of Gagauzia trained on overseeing the implementation of Moldova’s Association Agreement and DCFTA commitments.

1. The Rules of Procedure for the Parliament Women’s Caucus approved by the Coordination Council. A Roadmap of activities drafted for the Women MPs caucus. The Legislative Package 180 introducing a 40% quota for representation of either gender on the candidates’ lists of political parties for Parliamentary and local elections approved by Parliament. 2. Members of the Committee on Human Rights have enhanced understanding of the Universal Periodic Review (UPR) and their responsibilities in this regard. 8 MPs and 10 parliamentary staffers have participated in a practical workshop on the UPR. A Roadmap and Plan of Activities for 2016-2017, featuring hearings and field visits, have been developed for the Committee. 3. Moldova GOPAC chapter (anti-corruption caucus) was established. 9 Members of Parliament, representatives of different political groups, joined the Chapter. A Coordination Council was established. The secretariat of GOPAC Chapter was provided by UNDP. 4. Functional analyses of Secretariat of Parliament conducted. The final Report approved by the senior management of Parliament. A new Strategic Plan of Secretariat of Parliament was finalized and is pending approval by the Standing Bureau of Parliament. 5. The evaluation report on efficiency of PTIOs developed and presented to the parliament senior management. 6. Draft Communication Strategy of Secretariat of Parliament was developed and is pending approval by the Standing Bureau of Parliament. SOP on parliamentary transparency and access to information was developed. A Roadmap for achieving parliamentary openness was developed. 7. 15 MPs, 30 parliamentary staffers, 5 from Gagauz People’s Assembly trained on parliamentary oversight of the European Integration process in the Republic of Moldova.

description.narrative: Elections - elections

1. Centre for Continuous Electoral Training has improved capacities and training curricula, methodologies and materials, as well as a pool of certified electoral trainers (at least 40) available 2. Electoral reforms supported through provision of expertise and facilitation of dialog and consultations with Civil Society Organisations and general public on the reform actions 3. Political parties finance transparency improved through expertise and training for the implementation of the law on political party financing 4. Central Electoral Commission has a modern population register with an addresses system and inter-operable with other key state registers

comment.narrative: 1. Centre for Continuous Electoral Training lacks basic capacity to organize and conduct electoral training as this is a new institution: lack of training modules, materials, curricula; lack of a pool of professional trainers 2. Electoral reform needed in the areas of electoral administration; electoral systems; voter registration, as indicated in several OSCE/ODIHR reports 3. Law on political party financing absent 4. The State and Central Electoral Commission lacks a modern population register with an address system, integrated with other key state registers

1. N/A Target achieved in 2016 2. N/A Target Achieved in 2016 3. N/A Target reflected under the new Elections Project; 4.1 Target fully achieved. The first phase of the development of the new IT based Address Register is completed. Phases 2-5 are in the procurement process under the new Election Project, 2017, Q3. 4.2 50% completed due to new requirements coming from the Beneficiary. From security reasons for highly classified state information, the Ministry of Defense had to revise the interoperability of data and foresaw a proxy database to be connected not the live Register. This new prerequisite required a substantive change in the already developed technical design of the new system. The Company did not see itself in the financial position to redo the work in the given time-frame. The contract was terminated in mutual understanding. 4.3 Not achieved. Due to an unplanned change of the Electoral System and the long uncertainty on the exact legal provisions modifications, the design of an overall Reporting Module was not feasible any longer. The SAISE and its separate modules will need to be adjusted to the new Electoral System requirements first. The Reporting Module is planned to be developed under the new Elections Project in 2018. 4.4 Not achieved. With the new Electoral System, the Working Group on the revision of the Electoral Code was not relevant any longer.

comment.narrative: Training and education materials and approaches developed and applied during first MEBP phase

1. 1324 community leaders (including 1002 women and 322 men) managers of public institutions from beneficiary communities enhanced their knowledge in mobilization of local resources, management of biomass heating systems and sustainability and participative M&E of biomass heating projects. Another 80 mayors, school and kindergarten directors acquired necessary skills pertaining to sustainable procurement of solid biomass. 2. Up to 79 fuel suppliers participated in 6 regional training courses on the subject "Pellet and briquette production"and "Business management in the field of pellets and briquettes production" 3.More than 3100 pupils participated in the MEBP "Educational Innitiative" that includes: Spring School on RES in Transnistria, Summer School "Energel", optional course on RES for students from 7th - 9th grades taught in more than 100 schools, partnership with Moldova Ecological Movement, on-line webinars. 4. Educational Initiative on Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency for the school year 2015-2016 successfully completed. new activities have been set up with the Ministry of Education, for continuing educational initiatives in the next year. 5. Bioenergy Summer Camp “Energel” for best students engaged in the Educational Initiative successfully conducted. 6. Two educational programmes pertaining to renewable enrgy sources have been approved for piloting in three VET schools. The module on "Energy Plants" is piloted within VET Schools from Cuhurestii de Sus and Orhei while the module on "Operators in the biomass boiler room" is piloted within VET School Nr.3 from Chisinau. The curriculum for both occupations have been approved by the Ministry of Education 7. 1002 women and 322 men have been trained in subjects related to solid biomass during 2016.

1.Strengthened capacity of the key-stakeholders in the biomass sectors - more than 1335 local leaders improved their capacities in aspects related to efficient management of biomass technologies, sustainable maintenance of biomass boilers and efficient procurement of solid biofuel. 2.321 biofuel producers deepened their knowledge and abilities to access financing for market development and for policy oriented advocacy, to create new partnerships and platforms, such as Biomass Association and Biomass Cluster, and EU standards and regulations related to solid biomass production. 3.Strengthened capacities of the educational institutions in providing educational services on RES: more than 3500 young people have studied the optional course on RES and participated in the first National Olympiad on RES. 4.57 young people from the vocational schools of Orhei and of Cuhurestii de Sus, which are piloting the modules on energy plants within the Sylviculturist speciality have graduated in 2017. The optional courses gave been institutionalized by the Ministry of Education and have become part of the national VET curriculum. 5.First national accredited Trening Center for Biomass Operators established: 9 training sessions were conducted for 138 operators from approx. 57 communities. Operators were enrolled in the 40-hour academic course, being accommodated in the Training Centre’s hostel. After the training course, the certificates of professional skills have been awarded to operators who have passed the exam.

description.narrative: 1. National adaptation planning (NAP) roadmap developed, approved and under implementation and guides for at least 3 priority sectors elaborated and distributed through workshops and existing knowledge dissemination channels and relevant planners trained in mainstreaming climate change adaptation considerations into policy documents (out of which at least 50% women). 3. Data management and service quality in SHS improvement initiated; at least 5 climate change adaptation interventions designed and under implementation; at least 10 climate change adaptation interventions designed

comment.narrative: 1: The sectors and local governments lack climate change adaptation responsive policies and plans 2: Methodologies and tools for a coherent national adaptation planning process is not available in Moldova and the relevant government entities have limited knowledge for adaptation planning and budgeting. 3. No partnership in the area of climate change adaptation are available 4. Data management in SHS is not aligned with EU standards; no adaptation interventions piloted so far and no lessons learned in the adaptation planning available

comment.narrative: 1. Qualification of at least 30 NHRI staff was raised through exposure to international experience and training activities, including study visits, international and national conferences and meetings on human rights (at least 15 NHRI representatives, 9 women and 7 men), as well as 12 specialised three-day training courses on human rights and equality issues (21 NHRIs staff, 18 women, 3 men) as well as a Training of Trainers module (10 persons, 7 women, 3 men) ; 2. Diversity, including gender diversity, mainstreamed into the employment rules and regulations of the NHRIs through the use of improved HR tools and methodologies (developed in cooperation with two national experts, one for each NHRI) (22 Action Plans developed for NHRIs' subdivisions; more than 10 organizational regulations developed/revised; 63 job descriptions elaborated/revised; 7 guides on organizational management put into application.) 3. Equality Council's case management improved through the development and launch of a specialized software, designed to automatize the Council's working processes on cases, as well as to produce reports containing gender disaggregated data. As a result, a working tool is in place to solve systematic issues of case backlogs and backlog significantly reduced. At the same time, as a result of capacity building activities involving international expertise, the Equality Council has increased capacities on using legal technics, analysis, argumentation in drafting decisions and generally improved decisions drafting skills. 4. More than 30 Equality Council decisions were translated from Romanian into Russian, 40 into English and published on the web-site. Also, two Equality Council annual reports from 2013 and 2014 were translated from Romanian into English. More than 40 informative bulletins and articles were translated for the Ombudsperson Office into both Russian and English, as well as 58 news of the Equality Council were translated into Russian. This expanded the audie
1. Capacities of the NHRIs built in the human rights mainstreaming into the policies and legislation.

1. Human Rights and Equality Impact Assessment (HREIA) Methodology for the NHRIs elaborated for the analysis of national policies and legislation. Two-day training workshop delivered in March 2017 for the NHRIs and civil servants from Moldova’s governmental institutions on the application of the HREIA Methodology and the improvement of policies and legislation.

1. DSPs for Soroca and Stefan Voda districts (204136.98 ha), built on the Socio-Economic District Development Strategy, and benefited from participatory discussions during the entire process, are in the process of official consultation prior to be sent to the ministries for official approval.. The LUPs for Zastinca, Badiceni, Talmaza and Copceac communities passed the official consultation process and are submitted to the community councils for approval. 2. The new Forestry Code, which should ensure that the biodiversity issues will be taken into account during all forestry related planning is developed and sent to the Ministry of Environment to be further initiated the consultation process with in-line Ministries. 3. The project finalized the field inventory of the Red list species and developed species passports and conservation recommendations. Both passports and conservation recommendations were agreed with local public authorities, environmental inspection and forestry authorities. Based on the inventory findings a Handbook on habitats of rare plant and animal species in Soroca and Stefan Voda districts was developed. Information panels were installed in mayors’ offices of the two target districts to get the local population acknowledged biodiversity values in the region. 4. . Methodological recommendation for pasture management are part of the developed pasture management plans. In order to monitor the pasture productivity, the project is performing periodical measurements of the pasture productivity and vegetal cover. In 2017 the measurements that the overall productivity increased twice compare to the baseline. 5. The project has initiated the contracting of a dedicated company to develop and deliver the envisaged training activities, however this has been purposefully delayed by the project due to the on-going institutional reform. 1. The previous National Employment Strategy expired in December 2015, it has never been evaluated 2. Weak capacity of the MLSPF to assess and develop employment policies, as well as to lead the inter-ministerial coordination process on employment policy development 3. Very poor experience of MPSF in conducting public debates on employment policies 4. Lack of an institutional framework (regulations, procedures, designated staff) for supporting the reintegration of returned migrants at NEA 5. Poor capacity of NEA staff to provide adjusted reintegration services to returned migrants; 6. Lack of adjusted services, and poor data on migrants beneficiaries of NEA services 8. Migrants’ satisfaction with NEA/TEA services poorly assessed. 9. Referral sporadically and non-systemically done 10. N/A 11. None existing model at national level of fostering migrant 12.N/A 13.N/A 14.N/A 15.N/A
16. Weak diaspora engagement in local initiatives; 17.One functional association HomeTown Association in Selemet 18. Less than 50% of the target local authorities have functional webpages and social media profiles 19.N/A 20.N/A 21.N/A

1. Achieved – draft NES 2017-2021 developed in a participatory manner and submitted for official approval 2. Achieved: Two workshops for the inter-ministerial technical working group and three bilateral meetings of the MLSPF on designing NES 2017-2021 organized 3. Achieved: Seven public consultations on the draft NES were organized - four in Chisinau and three in Cahul, Balti and Comrat with circa 188 local stakeholders from public institutions, civil society, business and employees associations, educational institutions, local employment agencies, local and regional public authorities; One press event organized on employment issues; Two workshops on synchronizing the draft National Employment Strategy and the draft employment Strategy organized. 4. Partially - Updated Terms of references and operations’ manual for the institutionalization of reintegration focal points accepted by NEA – to be enforced starting 2016; 5. Achieved: Report on TEAs capacity developed, capacity building programme for TEA reintegration focal points developed; 10 pilot TEAs selected based on specific methodology and approved by NEA 6. Achieved: Two training modules of 2,5 days each, 10 coaching sessions and two networking events on migration, communication, service improvement, team building, etc. delivered to 74 national and local reintegration focal points which have knowledge, skills and regulations/procedures in place to provide better services to returned migrants (including up to 19% men); One training, of two days delivered to 25 non-pilot reintegration focal points. 7.2500 migrants benefited from adjusted services of NEA 8. Achieved: Report reflecting migrants’ perspective and views on the services provided by NEA developed, using user-led and innovative research tools. 9. Achieved: Concept of the reintegration referral mechanism drafted and consulted with NEA; two round tables organized to present and consult the referral network for reintegrating returned migrants to the main st

1. MLSPF supported in implementing the provisions related to migration from the NES 2017-2021 2. MLSPF supported in leading the inter-institutional coordination on implementing NES 2017-2021 3. N/A – achieved in 2016 4. Regulations and procedures for the institutionalization of reintegration focal points enforced by NEA; support to NEA in the official institutionalization of the reintegration focal points 5. Capacity assessment of the reintegration focal points 6. Advance capacity building of the reintegration focal points from the entire network of NEA, model of employment reintegration service provision piloted in 10 in Territorial Employment Agencies 7. At least 1200 returnees benefit from integrated employment reintegration services 8.Methodology for assessing the beneficiary’s satisfaction developed and submitted to NEA 9. Referral mechanism piloted, defined and proposed to NEA, MLSPF for approval and implementation nation-wide 10. At least 20 Home Town Associations functional and registered with full legal capacity; Over 100 HTAs presidents and active members capacitates enhanced (on HTA management, fundraising and communication) 18.25 target communities have capacities to plan and implement communication campaigns 19.Coaching conducted for 15 LPAs 20.At least one public event in 20 target communities for/with diaspora 21.SMS communication tool piloted by 10 communities; webpages of 25 local authorities functi

1. MHLSP and NEA supported in learning alternative options for reorganizing functional and operational aspects of NEA; as well as strengthened the capacity of NEA to provide support to returned migrants and refer them to other public institutions, when necessary. 2. Circa 2000 returnees benefit from NEA’s services. 8. Assessment tool drafted, guide for reintegration focal points drafted and submitted to NEA. 9. comment.narrative: 1.11% of the EU Directives and Regulations included in the Association Agreement are transposed in the national legislation. 2.An ineffective parliamentary oversight on the EU integration agenda. 3.Underdeveloped cooperation between Parliament and independent institutions (Ombudsman, Court of Accounts) 4.The cooperation between Parliament and CSOs, media and citizens is rather weak. 5.There are weak systems and processes for information management within the Parliament.

1. Baseline Assessment of Committees and needs of Secretariat staff performed. 2. Draft Parliamentary Action Plan for Association Agreement and DCFTA, tracking and reporting mechanism developed. 3. Roadmap and Plan of Activities for Committee on Human Rights developed. 4. A detailed roadmap for achieving parliamentary openness developed. At least 20 MPs and 30 parliamentary staff trained on Open Parliament principles and Open Data standards 5. A detailed roadmap on the implementation of E-Parliament developed.

1. Partially achieved. A service provider to perform the Baseline Assessment of Committees contracted. The task will be finalized by February, 2017. 2. The Parliamentary Action Plan for Association Agreement and DCFTA as well as the tracking and reporting mechanism were developed and presented to Parliament. 3. Roadmap and Plan of Activities for Committee on Human Rights developed and presented to Parliament. 4. Partially achieved. A Roadmap for achieving parliamentary openness was developed. 34 parliamentary staffers and 15 representatives of CSOs were trained on engaging through dialogue with civil society in parliamentary processes (legislative, oversight and budget). No MPs were trained. 5. Achieved. Future ICT Architecture Document of PRM (To Be Vision) was developed. A draft ICT Transformation Plan and the technical specifications for the development of the IT system e-Parliament developed.

1. A Capacity Development Plan for committee advisers and staff of Secretariat developed 2. A functional review of Gagauz People’s Assembly performed 5. Specialised software solutions for E-archive and e-evidence of assets implemented

1. Achieved. A thorough Baseline assessment of parliamentary committees was conducted. Their capacity development needs were identified and included into a draft Capacity Development Plan. 2. Achieved. A system of quantitative indicators that form the basis of a monitoring and reporting mechanism on the Parliament’s activity in the European integration process developed. The Parliament decided to pilot the monitoring and reporting mechanism on EU-related matters for 12 months. The development of the first draft Progress Report on Parliament’s activity related to European integration process is ongoing. 3. Partially achieved. A first draft Open Parliament Action Plan was developed. However it requires further consultation with CSOs and approval of parliament's leadership.. 4. Achieved. The Functional Analyses Report on Gagauz People’s Assembly produced. The development of the first Strategic Development Plan is in progress. 5. Achieved. 660.000 documents from the Parliament’s Archive were digitised. All files migrated into a software solution for e-archive. MPs and parliamentary staff have access to the e-Archive. The information system for e-evidence of assets was implemented in partnership with Moldovan Parliament. Specialised scanning and printing equipment was purchased by Project. The first inventory using the new software solution has already started.

comment.narrative: 1. Lack of water supply and sanitation systems in Taraclia district (only 85% of the existing systems are operational), thus limited access to clean and safe water (as to Taraclia town specifficaly, only half of the inhabitants have access to water, as only one water station is functional that does not cover the entire town) 2. Limited conditions in the Taraclia University dormitory 3. Limited capacities of the LPAs from Taraclia district to prioritize, fund and implement the improvement of local services

1. 32,360 persons from 8 local communities in Taraclia district have access to safe and clean water (Taraclia town, Tvardita, Valea Perjei, Corten, Cairaclia, Albota de Jos, Albota de Sus, Cortenul Nou) 2. Improved educational conditions for students of Taraclia University dormitory 3. Improved capacity of representatives of local public administration in 8 local communities in Taraclia district

1. 29,987 people (est. 14,167 men and 18,820 women) from 7 communities in Taraclia district have access to safe and clean water (Taraclia town, Tvardita, Valea Perjei, Cairaclia, Albota de Jos, Cealic, Ciumai). By installing the second water station in Taraclia town, it has been ensured that the whole town population has access to clean water. As to the 8th local community, in coordination with Taraclia District Administration, the Corten LPA will be supported to apply for funding through the on-going EU-funded Support to Agriculture and Rural Development (SARD) Programme implemented by UNDP in ATU Gagauzia and Taraclia District. 2. Improved educational conditions for students of Taraclia University dormitory through renovation of the dormitory roof 3. Improved capacity of representatives of LPAs in 7 local communities in Taraclia district by assisting them in the planning, design, implementing and monitoring of the water stations renovation projects
Complete outside finishing works at all 7 water access stations. Initiate a water access station project at Corten through related SARD Project funding.

All 7 water stations are fully completed and inauguration was held on May 2017. The Corten and Salcia water projects were approved and wil be financed through SARD project. Corten water station is to be completed by the end of 2017. Salcia water station is to be completed first part of 2018.

comment.narrative: There is dispersed information about the potential of companies from the Left Bank of the Nistru River to trade internationally. To assess the potential of the market participants from the Transnistria region to integrate in local, regional and global trade facilitation frameworks, there is a need for a structural analysis identifying main industries with export potential, as well as the bottlenecks for enterprises from the selected industries. This analysis would propose practical solutions to be supported as part of a follow-up technical assistance project.
